front.p: 1842 September 17 to his mother Amelia Hadfield (nee White)

body.p: I have just heard of an opportunity of writing by a good means of conveyance & therefore tho’ I have only a minute or two to devote to writing I do write. I have by the last vessel recd. four letters dated March & April from yourself, my father, Amelia, Charles & Maria. Tho’ some must have been lost I am thankful to have heard from you.

I came over here yesterday with Mr. Mason to meet the Bishop & am highly delighted with him. I breakfasted with him this morning: & he was very kind, saying that he had sufficient introduction to me from the Bishop of Australia who had spoken to him of me. He appears to be a man of great talent, energy & activity, in fact a first-rate man. I do now hope that we may expect an abundant blessing from the Lord upon our labours here.
I have been engaged much as usual among my people lately. I wrote to Caroline a few days ago & nothing has occurred since.
I administered the sacrament on Sunday to more than 150 natives at Waikanae, & on the Sunday previous to 65. I am much interested in my work.
I was grieved to hear that George had been again obliged to withdraw from his work on account of his health.

The account you give of Alexander is gratifying. Excuse these very hurried lines – but as the Brougham, which conveyed a former letter in three months is to convey this, I hope you will receive it shortly.
With kindest love to yourself & all the dear party at home.

P.S. I have just seen a box which I believe is the one forwarded from home, I have not opened it – I have heard lately from the Dawsons, they are quite well, Mr. Paddock, a relation of his, died here a fortnight ago.
